When the variable part of the field is nearly adjusted, it often happens 
that the constant white light from the mirror appears tinged with 
the complementary colour. This is an indication of what is required 
to make the resemblance of the two parts of the field of view perfect. 
When no difference can be detected between the two parts of the 
field, either in colour or in brightness, <s>then<\s> the observer must 
look away for some time, to relieve the strain on the eye and 
then <s>make a fresh observation<\s> look again. If the eye thus refreshed 
still judges the two parts of the field to be equal, the observation 
may be considered complete, and the operator must measure 
the breadth of each slit by means of the wedge, as before described 
and write down the result as a colour=equation, thus - 
Oct 18. J 18.5(24) + 27(44) + 37(68) = W* (13) 
This equation means that on the 18th of October the observer I made an observation in which 
the breadth of the slit X was 18.5 as measured by the wedge while its 
centre was at the division (24) of the scale, <s>and<\s>  that the breadths of 
Y & Z were 27 & 37 and their positions (44) and (68) and that 
the illumination produced by these slits was exactly equal, in my 
estimation, to the constant white W. 
I then shifted the position of the slit X from (24) to (28) 
and when the proper adjustments were made, I found a second 
colour equation of this form - 
Oct 18 J 16(28) + <s>[text?]<\s> 21(44) + 37(68) = W (14) 
Subtracting one equation from the other and remembering that 
the figures in brackets are merely symbols of position, not of magnitude 
we find - 
16(28) = 18.5(24) + 6(44)
